title: fix tuple of one issue
body: Fixes https://github.com/willmcgugan/rich/issues/445

title: [BUG] Pretty printing can break tuples containing a single item when expanding
body:
When pretty printing a tuple with one item, the pretty printing omits the comma necessary to make it a tuple.

For instance if you pretty print `(1,)` with `expand_all=True`, you get this:

```
(
    1
)
```

Which is no longer a tuple. If the tuple is not expanded then the result is `(1,)` which is correct.

title: Ansi decoder
body:
Implements an "ansi decoder" which converts strings with ansi codes in to a Text instance.

This is enabled in Progress bars, so stuff printed outside of Rich can still be exported to html.

title: rich handler refactor
body: Factored out method RichHandler.get_style_and_level to allow overriding in subclasses.

title: [REQUEST] More examples
body:
The [examples](https://github.com/willmcgugan/rich/tree/master/examples) directory contains a few .py files that demonstrate a feature of Rich.

It would be nice to have more of these.  No example should short and succinct, demonstrate a feature well, non-trivial, and shouldn't cover features that already exist.

title: new link ids
body:
Adds a link id to the Style class. Link ids are used when generating the ansi codes for links, so that the terminal knows which cells to highlight.

Formerly if a link contained multiple styles, the terminal would highlight individually styled portions of text on hover rather than the entire link. 

For example, printing this would look like the words ``Hello`` and ``World`` were two links, when they are actually one link.

"[link=https://example.org]Hello [b]World![/b][/link]"

This PR fixes that.


## Type of changes

- [ ] Bug fix
- [x] New feature
- [ ] Documentation / docstrings
- [ ] Tests
- [ ] Other

title: Improve test coverage
body:
Test coverage is currently siting at 89%. I'd love to get that up to high nineties before a 1.0.0 release.

If you can, contribute a test. Even if it only adds a single line to coverage, it would be appreciated!
